265167: Animate Dead.author: DarthParallax
265167: Animate Dead.text_parsed:
This is the best reanimation spell, hands down, for this reason:

I could honestly see this card getting reprinted into an actual Standard-Legal set thanks to Naturalize, if only the effect could be reworded in a way that is just more concise and readable--

Reanimation Ritual 1B
Enchantment

When Reanimation Ritual enters the battlefield, return a creature card in a graveyard to the battlefield under your control with a -1/-1 counter on it. When Reanimation Ritual leaves the battlefield, sacrifice that creature.


Well?
Advantage of using the -1/-1 counter would be to reduce exploiting hasty creatures with 1 toughness. Exhibit A: Ball Lightning.
265167: Animate Dead.text_posted:
This is the best reanimation spell, hands down, for this reason:

Enchantment

When Reanimation Ritual enters the battlefield, return a creature card in a graveyard to the battlefield under your control with a -1/-1 counter on it. When Reanimation Ritual leaves the battlefield, sacrifice that creature.

265167: Animate Dead.author: dustmop
265167: Animate Dead.text_parsed:
@The_Wolf

That wording wouldn't work. An "enchant creature" spell needs a creature target in order to be cast, which is why this new version starts with "enchant creature card in a graveyard" - it targets a creature in the graveyard. For the same reason, the original version used "enchant dead creature" because it looked for a target in the graveyard; the problem with that being that once the creature leaves the graveyard its no longer dead.

270446: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.author: brunsbr103
270446: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.text_parsed:
Erm, Ezuna, neither of those would take care of him. And he does have protection; it's part of the card. That's like saying tht if he didn't have flying i could block him with my phyrexian colossus.

EDIT: k bro

Chainsmoker's right; i'd have to pack mass removal or some colorless cards in a red/green deck if I wanted to get rid of him.

Sure other artifact creatures can easily be taken care of by red and green, but not this guy. Which in part is why it's relevant that he DOES have protection from red and green, aside from them being not part of Esper's color scheme.

also there is a possible reference to The Birds here. The film has a theme of colors, specifically green and red. A sphinx is also usually not as aggressive as the flavor text suggests, similarly to how the birds in the film are more aggressive to normal. Plus a Sphinx is basically a giant bird-woman-lion, so...

although I'm probably just making connections in my head

270446: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.author: drpvfx
270446: Sphinx of the Steel Wind.text_parsed:
Super powerful, yet also well balanced (unlike Ms. Baneslayer)-
three mana colors makes *all* the difference.

Of course, that's kind of irrelevant when the idea here is to cheat it into play ;-)

EDIT- Incoming Dark Ascension card could potentially dethrone/supplement this card in some decks,
including reanimator:

Drogskol Reaver
5WU
Creature - Spirit
3/5
Flying, Double Strike, Lifelink
Whenever you gain life, draw a card.

Color me impressed- it's not as hardy as the Sphinx here,
but drawing one or two cards pretty much every time it attacks or blocks
(thank you, Double Strike!) is a HUGE plus.
The CC is steep, but this is clearly great for reanimation-
now I'm even more curious what new types of reanimation we might see.

270449: Blazing Archon.author: DefectiveHeadMeat
270449: Blazing Archon.text_parsed: I was playing against a guy who's been playing for way longer then I have that INSISTED that "Can't attack you" included your creatures, was he right?
270449: Blazing Archon.text_posted: I was playing against a guy who's been playing for way longer then I have that INSISTED that "Can't attack you" included your creatures, was he right?

270449: Blazing Archon.author: SpencerDub
270449: Blazing Archon.text_parsed:
"I was playing against a guy who's been playing for way longer then I have that INSISTED that "Can't attack you" included your creatures, was he right?"
-DefectiveHeadMeat

Yes, he's right... but even without Blazing Archon out, you can't attack creatures.

In Magic, the only things that creatures can attack are players and planeswalkers. You don't get to say, "Alright, Bill, I'm attacking your Gladecover Scout with my Walking Corpse". All you can do is send your creatures at an opponent's (or an opposing planeswalker's) face, and that opponent gets to choose how they block, if at all. You can't attack creatures.

As Blazing Archon says, if your opponent has it on the field, you can't attack them. If they happen to have a planeswalker like Gideon Jura on the battlefield, you can attack that planeswalker, and your opponent can choose to block as he or she sees fit, but if they don't have a planeswalker, then you simply can't attack them.

You may be confused by the "fight" mechanic, as seen on cards like Prey Upon. In this mechanic, both creatures deal damage to each other, but they still aren't, in terms of the rules of the game, attacking. (Every word used in Magic has a very specific meaning--even though "fighting" and "attacking" may seem similar in normal English, they refer to two separate mechanics in the game.) This means that if your opponent had a Blazing Archon out, you could still cast Prey Upon targeting the Archon, and, say, your Skaab Goliath. Because fighting isn't attacking, this would still be allowed, and once the Archon was dead, you could attack.

270453: Twisted Abomination.author: blurrymadness
270453: Twisted Abomination.text_parsed:
Not a bad card. Similar to Krosan Tusker, he's fat that can tutor your land up. The nice thing about *this* guy is that he tutors up a swamp (E.G. Dual lands if you have them!) and does it for 2 mana. None of the other finishers in Green or Black (or any color as far as I could tell) were as strong of a finisher as this guy, as Regenerate takes an entire host of kill spells out of the picture:
-Most burn spells
-Pestilence effects
-Most combat damage
-Most black and black/x kill spells (either they can't target him, or he can regen)

Swamp cycling is for:
-Control decks (like one I run with him) where you *really* need at least 3 mana to get rolling and you plan on getting 5-6 mana finishers later. He gives you that and does it for 2 mana, something that Krosan Tusker can't do, nor can most 2-drops without that being their entire function.

-It's for reanimator decks as it's free discard, card neutral, and it gets fat in the 'yard when it could normally be countered.

-It's for decks that splash black but only want to see 1-2 black mana *ever*. Swamp cycling gives you that, and a non-dead card later.

Remember: making a land drop T1,T2, and T3 is one of the most important things in the game; this guy gives you that (as you should try to keep hands with 2-3 mana in them.) It allows you to splash black yet reliably see it, without spending $100s of dollars on fetches and without using "enter's tapped" effects (which depend on the deck which you'd rather have)

270453: Twisted Abomination.author: Ferlord
270453: Twisted Abomination.text_parsed:
This is one of my favourite creatures in Magic, weirdly enough. It isn't a powerhouse, but it's got enough things on it to be useful when you need a creature or something else.

When you're playing mono-black EDH, you usually need some means to get lands. It's one reason why I think Liliana of the Dark Realms is sometimes a better play in mono-black than Liliana Vess. You could (or should) have Armillary Sphere and Wayfarer's Bauble, but once they're in the grave, they provide you with almost nothing else. Black is one of the worst colours for abusing Artifacts.

But a creature is a whole different story. Reanimation and Mortivore-esque abilities run rampant in Black. Because of this, something like Absorb Vis is not as good to play.

Long story short, this is a great creature. A 4.0 rating is exactly what this needs.

Long story short, this is a great creature. A 4.0 rating is exactly what this needs.

270456: Entomb.author: DarthParallax
270456: Entomb.text_parsed:
I actually like Brockdjwest's idea of putting Entomb and Disentomb together :)
It's kind of poetic, and still quite powerful: Essentially Demonic Tutor with an extra 'discard a card' rider.
A 'dumbed down' version of Reanimator COULD be fun to play in a casual setting?

There's also a small case to be made that simply building in variance, like a 3-1 split Exhume/Disentomb, is a way to play against Meddling Mage/Thought Hemorrhage/Surgical Extraction/Cranial Extraction/Runed Halo and similar cards that are supposed to silver bullet an opponent's combo pieces. It won't come up a lot, but it would kind of just plain suck if you managed to set up Entomb and Buried Alive to have the perfect set of creatures in your graveyard, then your opponent stole away all the cards you had to get them back out.

The min-max version of the deck is already known- I find thinking about unusual ways to build decks interesting, and the advantage of confusing your opponents by playing cards they don't expect could actually swing the game in your favor in a tight spot. Another reason to do it that way is to preserve the identity of Magic: people who talked about the skill testing nature of Caw-Blade vs. Caw Blade and tried to argue about how interesting it was were missing the point that they were basically playing Black vs White Chess. Chess IS an interesting, fun, skill-testing, complex game. But it's not MAGIC. Caw Blade vs. Caw Blade was not MAGIC either.

On the topic of variance AND poetics, I am going to try and acquire the Duels of the Planeswalkers Promo Grave Titan, because I think he would be a pretty snazzy beast for this deck. ^^
When you're talking about turn 2 summons, I prefer beaters to controllers: might as well end the game as quickly as possible, and reduce the number of turns your opponent has to play without any hope.

270459: Putrid Imp.author: Ferlord
270459: Putrid Imp.text_parsed:
This card is in some ways slightly better than Zombie Infestation. Allow me to create a Pros and Cons chart:

PROS

1. This has a better mana cost (1 CMC > 2 CMC :P)
2. You don't have to discard two cards: You only have to discard one card at a time.
3. It's a creature that could become a flying chump-blocker or a simple attacker.

CONS

1. It's not an Enchantment, which is much more difficult to deal with than creatures.
2. You don't get Zombie tokens as a result.
3... Umm... Zombie's are cool.

Subtract Con 3 and you can easily see why this is a greater choice over the Infestation.
Of course, if you were any respectable reanimation player, you'd have both.

One of the best T1 reanimator plays you can get with this guy is as follows:

Swamp -> {B}
Which pays for Dark Ritual.

~~~~~~~~~~~{B} Putrid Imp
__________/----discards fatty to make it a viable target of-
Dark Ritual--{B} Reanimate
``````````\----which brings out fatty who is then enchanted by-
~~~~~~~~~~~{B} Strength of Lunacy
```````````----that has been discarded by the Imp to meet Madness requirements-

Now your fatty has an additional +2/+1 and Protection from White.

270460: Sickening Dreams.author: Ragamander
270460: Sickening Dreams.text_parsed:
Once upon a time, I ran this in a Death's Shadow deck.

So, I have four lands (Swamp, two Mountains, and a Graven Cairns), and my hand has been almost wholly useless so far. Finally I top-deck a playable card: Abyssal Persecutor, but I have to keep it open as a blocker. My opponent attacks me down to 12. Next turn I draw up to 8 cards in hand, so I figure I might as well play a Death's Shadow as a pitiful 1/1. My opponent attacks me down to 8 life and casts Rhox, with mana open to regenerate. On my next turn I draw Sickening Dreams. I look at my hand, pause for a bit, and say, "I win." My opponent is still at 20.

I discard 6 cards to Sickening Dreams, bringing my opponent to 14 and me to 2, with 1 card left in my hand. He regenerates his Rhox (tapping it) but loses his other creatures, and my Abyssal Persecutor bites the dust. My Death's Shadow is pumped from a 5/5 to an 11/11 as it takes the 6 damage, so it survives. I attack my opponent from 14 to 3 and cast my last card: Lightning Bolt.

Good times.

270461: Diabolic Servitude.author: Ragamander
270461: Diabolic Servitude.text_parsed:
I disagree about Zombify being 99% better.

Diabolic Servitude means that if your creature dies, you don't have to wait to draw another reanimation spell, but you may have to wait for another creature to hit the 'yard. (Of course, you could already have multiple dudes in the graveyard from cards like Buried Alive and Intuition.) It is true, furthermore, that it is highly vulnerable to enchantment removal (a sac-engine for creatures would at least return Diabolic Servitude to your hand).

Zombify, on the other hand, means that if your creature dies, you don't have to wait to get another creature into the graveyard, but you may have to wait to draw into another reanimation spell. (Of course, you could have used draw engines to get extras, but the same engines should be allowing you to discard plenty of creatures to power Diabolic Servitude anyways.)

Furthermore, if your reanimated creature is exiled with any of a number of commonly-played spells (e.g. Swords to Plowshares, Path to Exile, Journey to Nowhere, Oblivion Ring, Detention Sphere), neither spell is functionally different.

Basically, it depends on (A) whether your opponent is running enchantment removal other than O-Ring and the Happyface Orb, and (B) whether your deck is more likely to run out of dead creatures or reanimation spells. (A) is often "no," (advantage: Diabolic Servitude), and I predict that (B) will often be "reanimation spells" (advantage: Diabolic Servitude).

Also, Diabolic Servitude can be abused with instant speed removal, in the same way as O-Ring. It's best with bounce, so that it doesn't miss out on it's whole self-recursion thing. Try Vedalken Mastermind, which means repeatable reanimation with no drawback.

As i indicated earlier in a persist/undying deck this is utterly bonkers because it gets around the one real downside to the card. This is the sort of card that is above average in many decks but very good with the right cards and it's not even at a build-around level. While i admit that almost all my experience with magic is casual this really seems like the sort of card that can shine given the right deck.

270462: Exhume.author: PauperCubist
270462: Exhume.text_parsed:
I actually had to cut this from my pauper cube because it's the ONLY card ever printed at common that can reanimate fatties. Most kitchen-sink cubes (everything goes in) get access to way more of these effects, which makes Re-animator a viable draft archetype. But having only such effect in a 360-card pauper cube means that a would-be necromancer can't count on seeing them during a draft, nor can he rely on drawing that one card from his deck during a game.

I'm probably the only one here who wants to see Wizards print another common similar to this card.

270473: Swamp.author: DarthParallax
270473: Swamp.text_parsed:
Wow Gatherer, really? This is a Basic Land. All the Basic Lands deserve a solid 4-4.5 star rating. They are good strong cards that are the mortar that holds most decks together. Even decks that have access to powerful Dual Lands or even non-Land sources of mana should respect the Basic Lands, and thanks to Wasteland, Anathemancer, Price of Progress and similar, few indeed decks are actually wholly devoid of Basics.

Moreover, this is a Swamp, and Swamp is actually a supported Basic Land type. (i.e.- plenty of cards specifically care about Swamps)
